quiz.title: Unit 8: Factor Markets (Quiz 3)
quiz.subtitle: AP Microeconomics — Monopsony, Imperfect Labor Markets, Wage Differentials
quiz.subject: AP Microeconomics
quiz.topic: Monopsony, MRC, Wage Differentials, Compensating Differentials

questions.question: A monopsony in the labor market exists when
options: there is only one seller of labor
there is only one buyer of labor
there are many buyers and sellers of labor
questions.explanation: A monopsony is a single buyer of labor (one firm hiring in a labor market), giving it market power to influence the wage.

questions.question: In a monopsony, the marginal resource cost (MRC) of labor is
questions.explanation: Because a monopsonist must raise the wage to attract more workers, the cost of hiring an additional worker (MRC) exceeds the wage paid to that worker.

questions.question: A profit‑maximizing monopsonist will hire labor up to the point where
questions.explanation: Like any firm, a monopsonist hires where marginal resource cost (MRC) equals marginal revenue product (MRP) to maximize profit.

questions.question: Compared to a competitive labor market, a monopsony results in
questions.explanation: A monopsonist restricts employment to keep the wage low, resulting in both fewer workers hired and a lower wage than under competition.

questions.question: Which of the following is a source of wage differentials?
questions.explanation: Wage differences arise from skill/education (human capital), job conditions (compensating differentials), discrimination, unionization, and geographic mobility.

questions.question: Compensating differentials refer to
options: higher pay for more productive workers
higher pay for jobs with undesirable conditions
wage differences caused by labor unions
questions.explanation: Compensating differentials are wage premiums paid to attract workers to jobs that are risky, stressful, or otherwise less desirable.

questions.question: If a monopsonist faces a minimum wage set above the monopsony wage but below the competitive wage, employment will likely
questions.explanation: A moderate minimum wage can raise the wage toward the competitive level while increasing employment under monopsony by making MRC equal to the wage up to that point.

questions.question: Which of the following best describes the labor supply curve facing a monopsonist?
questions.explanation: The monopsonist faces the market labor supply curve, which is upward sloping—to hire more workers, it must offer a higher wage.

questions.question: Human capital refers to
options: the skills and education that increase worker productivity
the total number of workers in an economy
questions.explanation: Human capital is the stock of knowledge, skills, and experience that makes workers more productive, often gained through education and training.

questions.question: In a bilateral monopoly (one union facing one monopsonist), the wage outcome is
options: indeterminate and depends on bargaining power
questions.explanation: Bilateral monopoly involves a single seller of labor (union) and a single buyer (monopsonist). The final wage is negotiated and depends on relative bargaining strength.

scoreMessages.90: Mastery of monopsony behavior, MRC > wage, wage differentials, and bilateral monopoly.
scoreMessages.70: Solid grasp; review monopsony hiring rule, effects of minimum wage on monopsony, and sources of wage differences.
scoreMessages.50: Needs practice distinguishing monopsony from competitive labor markets and understanding compensating differentials and human capital.
scoreMessages.0: Focus on monopsony definition (single buyer), MRC > wage, hiring where MRC = MRP, and causes of wage differentials.
